author: Sarah Edworthy
title: Crete's food odyssey: a cusine steeped in history
text: More holiday options in Greece Ubiquitous Cretan olives as Knossos suggest that 4,000 years ago the island’s inhabitants consumed the same products as today: oregano, thyme, bay, rosemary, lemons, seafood, pears, figs, quince and olives. Homer referred to the ‘liquid gold’ of olive oil; writers such as Athenaeus and Hippocrates described the way dishes were prepared and eaten. So strong is the culinary tradition that it has survived occupation by the Arabs (824-961), the Venetians (1204-1669) and the Ottomans (1669-1898). Rewarding place to start: The port of Chania Photo: Region of Crete Today, the international scientific community hail the "miracle of the Cretan diet" that gives its population a notably low occurrence of coronary disease and cancer. Food and wine thus form an integral aspect of life in Crete. Whether you observe olive picking, visit Cretan tavernas and farms or undertake a wine trail, you will relish a gastronomic passion gained over the centuries, all proffered with warm hospitality. The beautiful port of Chania is a rewarding place to start. Amble through the Old Town and the Venetian fortress and imbibe the atmosphere over pilaf rice, ofto (roast baby goat) and fresh salads. Abundant: olives nurtured under the Mediterranean sun Photo: Region of Crete The municipal market is a food-lovers’ paradise with its colourful array of specialist vendors purveying bread wreaths, graviera and anthotyro cheeses, and luxuriant staka butter – the final flourish in Cretan ‘wedding rice’ cooked in nutritious meaty broth. You will discover that restaurateurs across the island all serve a palate-pleasing local cuisine based on olive oil, herbs, cheese and fresh produce. Food and wine are an integral aspect of life in Crete Olives, nurtured under the Mediterranean sun and brushed by Aegean winds, are abundant and add earthy piquancy to bread, pies, meze, tomato-based sauces, stews and stuffings. Cheese lovers adore Crete. The annual per capita consumption of cheese in Greece is higher than in any other European country. Mouthwatering: Crete is a cheese-lover's paradise Photo: Region of Crete Cretan cheese, long considered the secret to the longevity of the islanders, is made solely from sheep or goat milk, or in combination. They come white and yellow, creamy and hard, fresh and mature, reflecting the landscapes on which the herds graze. Must-tries include graviera, which ranges from sweet to nutty, and Kefalograviera, used in moussaka and pastitsio. Fresh flavours: restaurateurs use local produce Photo: Crete Agronutritional Authority Crete is an important destination for wine appreciation. Not only do the indigenous varieties complement the local gastronomy, their production also embodies viticultural customs handed down from ancient times. Near Kato Zakros, archaeological finds attest to traditions dating back 4,000 years. The areas under vine lie in the north and are tended with artisanal reverence and sophisticated oenological techniques. Vines flourish, basking next to silvery olive groves and sheltered from the warm winds of the Libyan Sea. In the vineyards surrounding Chania, Rethymno and Heraklion, winemakers are happy to share their insights into the celebrated whites – Vilana, Vidiano, Dafni, Thrapsathiri, Malvazia di Candia, Muscat of Spina, and Plyto. Good wine vibes on the grapevine Photo: Wines of Crete Aficionados of red wine should look out for Kotsifali, Martilari, Liatiko, Tsardana and Romeiko varieties. No visit to Crete is complete without a nightcap of the divine, deep-red Marouvas. For more information, go to the Greece Tourist Board . Healthy choice: lower rates of coronary disease and cancer are credited to 'the Cretan diet? Photo: Crete Agronutritional Authority DAKOS SALAD (rusks with tomatoes and feta cheese) Photo: Crete Agronutritional Authority Serves 4 A traditional dish from the island of Crete. The secret behind the perfect dakos salad is to use ripe, organic, on-thevine tomatoes and goodquality extra virgin olive oil to create this light and refreshing dish, which is perfect for a summer’s day. INGREDIENTS 4 large Cretan barley rusks (available from Greek grocers) or other rusks 6 large tomatoes, cut into dice 3 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil 1-2 tablespoons capers, roughly chopped 1 tablespoon red-wine vinegar 150g feta cheese 50g myzithra or ricotta cheese 10-15 black olives, pitted and halved Salt and pepper to taste Oregano to serve PREPARATION Dip the rusks in water and then let them dry. Drizzle 1 tablespoon olive oil over them. Put the tomatoes, vinegar and two tablespoons of oil in a bowl, add a third of a teaspoon of salt and a good grind of black pepper, stir gently and set aside. Spread out the dakos on a platter and spoon the tomato mixture on top. Sprinkle over the cheese, olives and capers, and top with oregano and the remaining olive oil. SNAILS WITH ROSEMARY AND WINE Photo: Region of Crete INGREDIENTS 1 kg snails ½ water glass flour ½ water glass olive oil salt, pepper, rosemary ½ water glass red wine PREPARATION Salt the snails, flour them and cook in sizzling oil for 3 minutes, with their openings facing the pan. Add the rosemary, salt and pepper, stir, and 2 minutes later add the wine. Let them come to the boil and they are ready to serve. Another option is to prepare a batter, using flour, salt, pepper, oregano and garlic (optional). Fill the snails’ openings with this mixture and fry them in the oil and rosemary. • Read more about Greek cuisine at Holidays in Greece
